keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family reported he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up' at the airport.
Cagle was not armed at the time of arrest but was found with an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle outside the airport.

He faces multiple charges including terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assaults, possession of a firearm in commission of a felony, and being a convicted felon in possession of a firearm.

Cagle also faces federal charges related to attempted violence at an international airport, interstate communications containing threats to injure, and being a convicted felon in possession of a firearm.

The incident occurred at one of the world’s busiest airports, Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, which handled over 108 million passengers in 2024 and is a major hub for Delta Air Lines.
The FBI is assisting in the investigation, and authorities emphasized that the threat was averted due to early intervention by Cagle’s family and alert to law enforcement.
Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens stated that Cagle was mentally challenged and had a semi-automatic weapon, which combined posed a deadly risk.
Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem publicly commended law enforcement for preventing a potential tragedy.
Cagle was previously convicted of marijuana possession over two decades ago and lives in Cartersville, about an hour north of Atlanta.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Billy Joe Cagle, who lives in Cartersville, Georgia, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted authorities that he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up'. Although he was not armed at the time of arrest, police found an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle. Cagle faces both state and federal charges, including terroristic threats, attempted aggravated assaults, and possession of a firearm as a convicted felon. Authorities emphasize that the threat was averted due to early intervention by family and law enforcement. The incident occurred at one of the world’s busiest airports, which handles over 108 million passengers annually and is a major hub for Delta Air Lines. The FBI is assisting in the investigation, and officials including Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem praised the swift action that prevented a tragedy.
title: Man Arrested Inside Atlanta Airport After Making Threats to ‘Shoot It Up’
